titlestmt.titleproper: United States Strategic Bombing Survey : [Reports] (Pacific War)
titlestmt.subtitle: A Finding Aid to the Collection in the Library of Congress
titlestmt.author: Prepared by the Science, Technology & Business Division

publicationstmt.publisher: Science, Technology & Business Division, Library of Congress

profiledesc.creation: Finding aid encoded by Glenn R. Gardner 2013

did.head: Collection Summary
did.unittitle: United States Strategic Bombing Survey : [Reports] (Pacific War) 1945-1947

physdesc.label: Contents
physdesc.extent: 109 reports

repository.label: Location
repository.corpname: Science, Technology & Business Division Library of Congress

did.abstract: During World War II, the United States undertook massive aerial attacks against cities and industrial areas in the European and Pacific Theaters to destroy German and Japanese military forces. To study the effects of the bombing, the United States Strategic Bombing Survey (USSBS) was organized in November 1944. The USSBS was assigned two tasks: establish a basis for evaluating the importance and potential of air power as an instrument of military strategy; and, to plan the future development of the armed forces. The survey was originally conducted in Europe [European War reports]; the Pacific survey [Pacific War reports] was added after the surrender of Japan on August 15, 1945 by the order of President Harry S. Truman.

note.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the LC Online Catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically therein.

controlaccess.head: Titles
controlaccess.title: United States Strategic Bombing Survey (Series) (Pacific war)

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: Collection purchased by Library of Congress in 1969.

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: Reports with Library of Congress (LC) call numbers are part of the Library's General Collections. Selected Pacific War reports were also added to the PB collection by the U.S. Department of Commerce, Office of Technical Services, and are available in the Library's Technical Reports and Standards (TRS) Unit of the Science, Technology & Business Division.

processinfo.head: Location
processinfo.p: Science, Technology & Business Division, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

userestrict.head: Copyright Status
userestrict.p: Copyright in this collection of reports in the custody of the Library of Congress has been dedicated to the public.

accessrestrict.head: Access and Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Access to the collection is unrestricted.
Reports with LC call numbers can be requested from the Library's General Collections. Please note that some items may be held at offsite locations and may require additional time for retrieval.
Unclassed reports from the PB collection are available from the Technical Reports & Standards Unit, Science, Technology & Business Division. PB reports must be viewed in the Science Reading Room.

altformavail.head: Additional Forms Available
altformavail.p: United States Strategic Bombing Survey reports of the Pacific War are also available on microfilm in the Library's Microform & Electronic Resources Center as Microfilm 29945 (Catalog record: http://lccn.loc.gov/sn94094676). Copies may be ordered from the Photoduplication Service at the Library of Congress. Links have also been provided to digitized content, where known.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: United States Strategic Bombing Survey : [Reports] (Pacific War).

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Please note that 31 of the reports were reprinted in the publication United States Strategic Bombing Survey, a ten-volume series issued in 1976 by Garland Publishing, Inc. (Catalog record: http://lccn.loc.gov/75026396 ). Volumes 2-10 are in the Library's General Collections, under the LC call number D785.U57 1976.
The National Archives also holds records of the United States Strategic Bombing Survey (available at: http://www.archives.gov/research/guide-fed-records/groups/243.html).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: During World War II, the United States undertook massive aerial attacks against cities and industrial areas in the European and Pacific Theaters to destroy German and Japanese military forces. To study the effects of the bombing, the United States Strategic Bombing Survey (USSBS) was organized in November 1944. The USSBS was assigned two tasks: establish a basis for evaluating the importance and potential of air power as an instrument of military strategy; and, to plan the future development of the armed forces. The survey was originally conducted in Europe [European War reports]; the Pacific survey [Pacific War reports] was added after the surrender of Japan on August 15, 1945 by the order of President Harry S. Truman.

arrangement.head: Arrangement of the Records
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged in four series:

bibliography.head: Further Reading
bibliography.bibref:
Biddle, Tami Davis. Rhetoric and Reality in Air Warfare: The Evolution of British and American Ideas about Strategic Bombing, 1914-1945.
Princeton, N.J.: Princeton University Press, c2002. 406 p.
LC Call Number: UG705.G7B54 2002
Catalog Record: http://lccn.loc.gov/2001036865

Bombing Civilians: A Twentieth-Century History. Edited by Yuki Tanaka and Marilyn B. Young.
New York: New Press : Distributed by W.W. Norton, 2009. 291 p.
LC Call Number: D431.B66 2009
Catalog Record: http://lccn.loc.gov/2008027814

Grayling, A. C. Among the Dead Cities: The History and Moral Legacy of the WWII Bombing of Civilians in Germany and Japan.
New York: Walker and Co., 2006. 361 p.
LC Call Number: D790.2.G73 2006
Catalog Record: http://lccn.loc.gov/2005058597

A Guide to the Reports of The United States Strategic Bombing Survey. Edited by Gordon Daniels.
London: Offices of the Royal Historical Society, University College London, 1981. 115 p.
LC Call Number: D785.U63 Suppl.
Catalog Record: http://lccn.loc.gov/82187771

Knell, Hermann. To Destroy a City: Strategic Bombing and Its Human Consequences in World War II.
Cambridge, Mass.: Da Capo, 2003. 373 p.
LC Call Number: D757.9.W8K58 2003
Catalog Record: http://lccn.loc.gov/2003544951

MacIsaac, David. Strategic Bombing in World War Two: The Story of the United States Strategic Bombing Survey.
New York: Garland Pub. Co., 1976. 231 p.
LC Call Number: D785.U573M3
Catalog Record: http://lccn.loc.gov/75027037

Ross, Stewart Halsey. Strategic Bombing by the United States in World War II: The Myths and the Facts.
Jefferson, N.C.: McFarland & Co., c2003. 244 p.
LC Call Number: D785.U57R67 2003
Catalog Record: http://lccn.loc.gov/2002014698

Sebald, Winfried Georg. On the Natural History of Destruction. Translated by Anthea Bell.
New York: Modern Library, 2004. 202 p.
LC Call Number: PT405.S4313 2004
Catalog Record: http://lccn.loc.gov/2004269961

Swift, Daniel. Bomber County: the Poetry of a Lost Pilot's War.
New York: Farrar, Straus and Giroux, c2010. 269 p.
LC Call Number: PR605.W66S95 2010
Catalog Record: http://lccn.loc.gov/2010023402
